name: wood wool production | residual wood, dry | Cutoff, U
description:
ecoQuery: https://ecoquery.ecoinvent.org/3.10/cutoff/dataset/10468/documentation

From reception of industrial wood at the factory gatel. 

This activity ends with wood wool, at plant. The dataset includes all processes of wood wool production from industrial softwood (debarked), including air drying (from u=70 - 20%), external and internal transports, sucktion, air compression and sawmill production. The dataset does not include infrastructure.
category: C:Manufacturing/16:Manufacture of wood and of products of wood and cork, except furniture; manufacture of articles of straw and plaiting materials/161:Sawmilling and planing of wood/1610:Sawmilling and planing of wood

processDocumentation.geographyDescription: Data from the only Swiss wood wool production plant used for central Europe
processDocumentation.technologyDescription: Technology reflects a medium sized Swiss enterprise from 2000. ;Wood wool is produced mainly from spruce by machines similar to planing machines. The shavings are 0.03 to 0.5 mm thick and usually 2 mm wide. The input wood has to be dry (u<20 30%) and its length usually is around 50 cm.;;Reference:;Kollmann F. F. P., Kuenzi E. W. and Stamm A. J. (1975) Principles of Wood Science and Technology. Springer-Verl., Berlin, Heidelberg, New York. AND Nimz H., Schmitt U., Schwab E., Wittmann O. and Wolf F. (1997) Wood. In:  Ullmann's encyclopedia of indus-trial chemistry (ed. Anonymous). 5th edition on CD-ROM Edition. Wiley & Sons, London.

exchanges.description: Estimation. Based on personal communication to Lindner Produktion AG, Watwill (2002), Hr. Wildnagel. www.lindler.ch; Fax 071/9876159.

exchanges.description: Estimation. Based on personal communication to Lindner Produktion AG, Watwill (2002), Hr. Wildnagel. www.lindler.ch; Fax 071/9876159, AND Tachenbuch der Holzteknologie, p. 443 (see Source). Data contains all electricity consuming processes, incl. internal transports, suction, air compression, sawmill production for average years 2000 and 2001.
